Maynooth

Course Project | Web & Mobile

Client

Maynooth Furniture is a new business selling affordable high-end design furniture made in Ireland.

Primary objectives

To build a e-commerce website for people to browse & purchase furniture for home delivery

Description

My main focus for this project was simplicity, which during my research I found to be missing from the majority of competitor's websites. Things like newsletters and sale notifications tend to be very in-your-face and distracting, causing the guest to become confused, and frustrated. With that in mind, I went about creating a very simple, yet precise shopping experience.

Made with...

Deliverables

  • Wireframes for client approval
  • High fidelity prototypes
    • Desktop website
    • Mobile app
  • User Testing - Weâ€™ll be using Hallway testing & unmoderated remote testing
  • UI Assets for developers

Challenges & Goals

  • Create a full-fledged eCommerce experience from scratch
  • With simplicity in mind, create an elegant yet functional and efficient shopping experience
  • Have feature parity between the full desktop website and the mobile app

Homepage

With the homepage, I wanted there to be a very clear call to action with simple navigation. I chose not to include elements like newsletter signups and sales banners in the floating nav. Although I believe they could be added whilst still maintaining the simplified look I was going for.

The sections include "New & notable" "Inspiration" and a "Clearance" section, all of which have only necessary content and are designed to not only be eye-catching but easy to focus on and distinguish from one another.

I decided to place the newsletter sign up and all social media links in the footer so-as not to clutter the rest of the page. The company is local and less reliant on social media and newsletter signups for traffic so keeping them towards the bottom, away from the main content helps keep the focus on the rest of the page.

Category page

With the category pages, simplicity becomes very important. It's very easy to make a page like this very cluttered and not user-friendly. One of my main concerns was implementing the "Inspiration" section in an elegant and effective way. It had to be eye-catching yet simple so I went with three different shaped cards with the main inspiration photos behind the main text.

Product page

With the product page, I took inspiration from pretty much every other product page out there. Obviously, the item and the details of said item are the most important part of this page so I wanted to highlight them in an effective manner right at the top then gave the more nitty-gritty details a full-width section just below. I decided to move the reviews to the bottom just after the "Related" sections, forcing users to at least glance at the familiar product cards which are seen through-out the site.

Hindsight

There are definitely things that I would've/will do differently, but since this project is still on-going I have time to correct certain mistakes that I've made. The goal is to never stop learning and to constantly look at not only what you can improve, but how you can improve them

The app

The app, much like most of this project is still a work in progress and is subject to many changes. The current prototype is based on the web version with some more elegant and eye-catching design cues like more rounded-corners, more blur and updated product cards

Thank you

Thanks for making it to the end! If you want more information, or have a question about anything, please feel free to head to the contact page or check out any of my social media links below.
